results.title: Cold war. Vol. 1. Episodes 1-4: Iron curtain
results.creator_credit: Jeremy Isaacs Productions, Turner Original Productions and Martin Smith
results.brief_description: This 24 episode television series presents an excellent biographical history of the Cold War, from the Russian Revolution in 1917 through to the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989. The battle between super powers America and the Soviet Union is told in great detail through over 600 exclusive interviews and personal narratives, newsreels and archival film footage which attempt to convey to the viewer some of the tensions and conflicts that threatened global peace during those years. Many major historical moments have been captured and provide an insight to the reasons as to how and why the Cold War, the Iron Curtain, East and West, and nuclear weapons became a part of our everyday life, particularly in the 1950s-1960s. Volume one features the first four episodes, covering the period from the Russian Revolution to the breaking of the Berlin blockade in 1949. Once allies against Hitler during World War II, the Soviet Union and the United States became divided over their political and economical ideologies post Nazi Germany with the US pushing for democracy and capitalism and the Soviet favouring expansionism and communism. As Central and Eastern Europe came under the control of Stalin and his puppet governments and the “Iron Curtain” was created, Germany and in particular, Berlin (divided into four occupied zones - US, British, Russian and French) became the focus of attention in the battle for ideological control. Berlin was blockaded and threatened with starvation by Stalin - the West’s response was the Berlin airlift. Meanwhile, to keep up with America’s nuclear capabilities the Soviets detonated their first atomic bomb on 29 August 1949. The American monopoly was over and so began the rise of the Super Powers and decades of confrontation. Narrated by Kenneth Branagh. (For more information see www.cnn.com/SPECIALS/cold.war)

results.title: Cold pizza
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Michael Rubbo, Tom Daly and Larry Kent
results.brief_description: This is an engaging story of young enterprise, pitfalls, and eventual success. It is about two young Greek boys of Montreal who try to earn some extra money for a trip to their homeland by delivering pizzas. The misadventures they encounter, and how they surmount them all, make an amusing story full of youthful initiative. (Awards: Buenos Aires; Cork; San Antonio)

results.title: Cold journey
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, George Pearson and Martin Defalco
results.brief_description: A feature drama about a young Canadian Indian’s attempt to find a place for himself. It tells of the cultural shock of an educational system that teaches him to be a white man, and of his attempts to discover a way of life more meaningful to his Native culture and ancestry. It is a tragic story of unexpected pitfalls and disillusionment that are as cruel as the bitter wind that greets him on his cold and lonely journey. The film stars Buckley Petawabano, Johnny Yesno and Chief Dan George, and was shot on location with the people of Indian reserves and schools in northern Saskatchewan and Manitoba.

results.title: Cold front
results.brief_description: Depicts the passage of a cold front breaking a summer heat wave. Blends the themes of the experience of weather in the city and the scientific concept of air masses and frontal systems.

results.title: Cold days = Hideg napok [NTSC]
results.brief_description: Considered one of the most important Hungarian films of the 1960s, “Cold Days’ courageously tackled the theme of the Hungarian role in World War II, a previously taboo subject within Hungarian society. The film is based on events that occurred in the winter of 1942, when the Hungarian Army massacred over 3,000 Serbian and Hungarian nationals, mostly Jews, in the town of Ujvidek (now Novi Sad, Serbia). Kovacs’ remarkable film about this incident is both a grim record of the atrocity as well as a meditation on the memory of it. The film is structured around the recollections and self-justification of four men involved in the massacre as they await trial in 1946. Stark black and white photography conveys an atmosphere of coldness and remoteness, visually linking the emotional detachment and denials of the perpetrators with stark images of the massacre itself. Based on the short novel by Tibor Cseres. Cast includes Zoltan Latinovits, Ivan Darvas, Adam Szirtes and Ibor Szilagyi.

results.title: Cold comfort: Australia's nuclear responsibilities
results.creator_credit: Open Channel Productions and Jack White
results.brief_description: Cold Comfort is a lively and incisive documentary on the local and global consequences of the decision to export Australian uranium. It presents statements by those who support the mining of uranium for nuclear energy purposes, alongside those who oppose it. The program incorporates archival footage, and contemporary interviews to chart Australia’s participation in atomic history. Presented in four sequences. “The Uranium debate”, “The History of the bomb”, “Transportation of radioactive waste” and “Fallout from Chernobyl and Three Mile Island”.

results.title: Cold comfort
results.creator_credit: Tasmanian Film Corporation, Don Anderson and Damian Brown
results.brief_description: Highlights the potential danger from bacteria if frozen food is incorrectly handled. The key is to maintain strict temperature control. Covers all aspects from the handling of fresh food by the processor through freezing, storage transportation in refrigerated containers or trucks, handling by supermarkets and other sales outlets, transportation by the consumer and handling in the home. Suitabvle for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Cold Chisel: last stand
results.creator_credit: Next Vision, John McLean and Tony Stevens
results.brief_description: For 10 years Cold Chisel defied the trends of industry conventions and inspired a legion of loyal fans which elevated them to a status unmatched in the history of Australian rock’n’roll. ‘Last stand’ is a feature length film which combines the story of Cold Chisel’s career, with multi-camera coverage of their farewell concert at the Sydney entertainment Centre in 1983. The film features live performances of 16 classical Chisel songs, with excerpts from many more underscoring the behind-the-scenes and archival footage. Interviews are conducted with band members Jimmy Barnes, Ian Moss, Don Walker, Phil Small and Steve Prestwich, as well as other music industry colleagues. Features the following tracks: “Standing on the outside”, “Cheap wine”, “Rising sun”, “Khe sanh”, “Janelle”, “Twentieth century”, “You got nothing I want”, “Tomorrow”, “Star hotel”, “Choir girl”, “Bow river”, “Flame trees”, “Saturday night”, “Wild thing”, “Goodbye (Astrid goodbye)” and “Don’t let go”.

results.title: Cold can kill
results.brief_description: Presents the dangers of hypothermia and demonstrates preventive measures. Covers hypothermia caused by immersion in cold water and exposure to wind and low temperatures.
